meta.title: COVID-19 "Coronavirus" Update - Victor Central Schools

li.a: Victor Central School District Plan of Service for Special Education
A Parent's Guide to Special Education
Una guía para padres sobre educación especial
Visual and Performing Arts Hall of Fame
Visual and Performing Arts Hall of Fame
Parents Bill of Rights for Data Privacy and Security
Parents Bill of Rights for Data Privacy and Security
Visual and Performing Arts Hall of Fame

div.h2:
Stay Safe and Stay Well
Distance Learning and COVID-19 Updates

p.br:
Thanks for visiting this page, an important space dedicated to information on how the Victor Central School District is dealing with the effects of the Coronavirus. There is no doubt that we are all impacted by this situation. We feel for all community members confronted with the illness, either directly or indirectly. We also understand the hardship families are under with caring for your children during the day when they typically would be with us, and handling the stress of job responsibilities and the financial implications of this crisis.
This page is intended to make things easier for you to find important information, keep up with day to day communication, and connect with us if you have questions or concerns. There are lists of Resources below as well as information and updates under our subsections on the right hand side of the page. If you are on a mobile devise the subsections will be listed as a menu at the top of the page.
Please give us feedback regarding the efficiency of this specific site as well as any suggestions you may have.

em.strong: To see previous Town Hall Meetings

div.p: According to the CDC, the most important thing people can do to reduce infection is to practice good hand washing. Wash hands often with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds (or sing “Happy Birthday” twice). If clean water and soap are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. By practicing good hand washing and sanitizing, we can help stop the spread of germs.

In addition, please practice proper Social Distancing- please do not congregate in groups and when you're with others, try to stay 6 feet apart. This approach is challenging, but will save lives and allow all of us to go back to our normal routine in a shorter amount of time.

The COVID-19 (coronavirus) has understandably created anxiety for many watching it unfold around the world. Our children are watching, too. For more information about talking to children about COVID-19, please refer to this parent resource from the National Association of School Psychologists and the National Association of School Nurses:
https://www.nasponline.org/resources-and-publications/resources-and-podcasts/school-climate-safety-and-crisis/health-crisis-resources/talking-to-children-about-covid-19-(coronavirus)-a-parent-resource
The NYS Department of Health has also established a Novel Coronavirus Hotline at (888) 364-3065.
New York State Association of Counties

a.strong: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)

div.p: As we are hearing more about how to stay physically safe from Coronavirus and other illnesses, we would like to address the mental health needs that you may be seeing or feeling surrounding this topic. The constant conversations and media coverage can be distracting and overwhelming. You may notice a wide range of reactions to what is being reported, from excitement to potential changes in schedules to fear and anxiety of the unknown. Here are some common recommendations to follow:

ul.li: Allow time away from the topic by limiting access to news coverage/conversations
Focus on what can be controlled (i.e. social distancing, hand washing)
Model self-care (eat healthy meals, sleep well, exercise and take deep breaths to handle stress)
Let students know who, when and where they can go if they need to talk or need a break

div.p: The links below will provide more detailed information for staff, students and families.

p.a:
Preparing for Infectious Disease Epidemics:
Brief Tips for School Mental Health Professionals
Just for Kids: A Comic Exploring The New Coronavirus
Coronavirus Student Guide: Virus Explainer and News Updates
Talking with Children: Tips for Caregivers, Parents, and Teachers During Infectious Disease Outbreaks
Helping Families Cope with the Coronavirus Disease
Talking to Children about COVID-19 (Coronavirus) A Parent Resource
Care for Caregivers: Tips for Families and Educators
Helping Children after Tragic Events: Stop Watching, Start Talking

div.p: Internet Safety Tips for Parents

div.p: Our Mission:To Teach, To Learn, To Support, To Improve, To Achieve!
953 High Street, Victor, NY 14564

a.title: Powered by Finalsite opens in a new window

article.h2: BOE Meeting and VCS Town Hall

div.p: On Wednesday, April 22 at 8:00 am, the Victor Board of Education will hold a short meeting to vote on the BOCES Administrative Budget and BOCES Board Candidates. You can "attend" the meeting by going to the following link.

Join us for our weekly Town Hall meeting. The Thought Exchange will be open through Wednesday afternoon. We will use your feedback to shape the discussion at our Virtual Town Hall (hosted on our District Facebook page) discussion on the budget on April 22, 2020, starting at 6:30 PM.

This weeks question on Thought Exchange:
As a member of our school community, what are your questions, comments and concerns regarding the budget?
Thanks again for your continued engagement in our school community.

Please click on the following link:
https://my.thoughtexchange.com/#653165314/hub

article.h2: Budget Message From Superintendent Tim Terranova 4.18.20

div.p: While we continue to navigate the challenges related to COVID-19, we must also continue to operate our school district. A major focus moving forward is our school budget. Our District has experienced tremendous growth over the past 15 years, and funding has not kept pace with that growth. Specifically, we have the lowest per-pupil expenditure (total budget divided by # of students) in the entire state of NY, which impacts staffing in several areas as well as our ability to maintain appropriate savings (Reserves). In March, we communicated that we would be proposing a tax-cap override as a way to increase revenue to maintain the excellence for which our District is known.

Since we introduced this information, our community has experienced the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, both from a health and safety standpoint and an economic standpoint. At the April 16, 2020 Board of Education meeting, the District proposed a tentative budget that exceeded the tax cap but not at the level proposed in March. You can learn more about the budget by viewing a video from our discussion HERE.

The Board of Education would like your feedback regarding the VCSD budgetary plan. Please click HERE to enter our ThoughtExchange and submit feedback. The ThoughtExchange will be open through Wednesday afternoon. We will use your feedback to shape the discussion at our Virtual Town Hall (hosted on our District Facebook page) discussion on the budget on April 22, 2020, starting at 6:30 PM.
Thanks again for your continued engagement in our school community.
School buildings will remain closed through May 15th. Distance learning and food distribution will occur during this time.
